data.text:
Film Pitch

Film PitchMollieHabbershaw

This film pitch proposes a teen romance movie about a popular high school girl who breaks up with her boyfriend, one of the most popular boys in school. She turns to her geeky best friend for advice and comfort. Through flashbacks, it is revealed that the geeky friend has always had feelings for the girl but thought she wasn't his type. The girl comes to realize that personality is more important than looks, and she starts falling for her geeky friend. The film's message is that looks aren't everything and deeper qualities like personality are what really matter in a relationship. Inspiration is drawn from TV shows like 90210 and films like Geek Charming that follow a similar storyline.

Unit 51 pr9 sourcing images completed

Unit 51 pr9 sourcing images completedLydiaCharlotteCooke

Copyright is a legal right that grants creators exclusive control over the use and distribution of their original works, usually for a limited time period. While copyright provides creators control, it is not absolute and allows for limitations and exceptions like fair use. To avoid infringing on copyright, permission must be obtained from the copyright holder to use or change their protected materials, as the creator maintains legal rights over their work and can decide whether or not to grant permission and on what terms. When finding images, permission from the copyright holder or a paid license is required before using the image, even if the holder is not obvious, including images from Google, social media, books and photos taken by others. Certain organizations can grant licenses to use copyrighted images

Unit 51 pr9 sourcing images completed

Unit 51 pr9 sourcing images completedLydiaCharlotteCooke

Copyright provides creators exclusive rights over their original works for a limited time. These rights are not absolute and have limitations like fair use. To use copyrighted materials like images, you need permission from the copyright holder or a license, even if the holder is not obvious. There are organizations that can help you obtain licenses or permission to use images found online or elsewhere. Before using an image, you need to contact the copyright holder, pay any required fees, and get a license. If the holder cannot be identified, you may need to pay a fee to a group like Copyright Hub to help identify the owner and obtain permission.
